subject: Re: [junit] Re: JUnit vs. Agitator
msgSnippet: ... I do it the same way you do, but rather than check messages, I design exceptions that tell me about the problem with non-text data. The smell with checking
messageBody:
frogstar wrote:
>
> --- In junit@yahoogroups.com, "J. B. Rainsberger" <jbrains@...> wrote:
> >
> > Now I don't necessarily agree that checking an exception message is
> > /good design/. I also don't necessarily agree that having a negative
> > value for 'score' is cause for an exception--it depends where the
> system
> > boundaries are.
>
> In this case "points" was the count of JUnit or Agitator assertions --
> negative values were non-sensical.
>
> And I'm not sure checking the exception message in my test is a
> question of design at all, but out of curiousity, how do you TDD
> throwing an exception?

I do it the same way you do, but rather than check messages, I design
exceptions that tell me about the problem with non-text data. The smell
with checking exception messages is Primitive Obsession: specifically,
using text to represent something meaningful.

If Java had symbols (like Ruby does), then I would be able to have an
exception class like OutOfRangeException that takes a symbol, value and
acceptable range. Then I could expect this kind of exception:

new OutOfRangeException(:score, -5, Range.POSITIVE)

meaning that the symbol score, at value -5, is out of the range of [0,
MAX_INT).

Since we don't have symbols in Java, I would use a string to represent
the variable name. I don't like it, but I find it better than checking a
message that can easily change. The concept of "score" in a bowling game
class in unlikely to change name.

...and I'm not arguing that a negative score makes sense. I'm merely
saying that without system context, it might or might not make sense for
this class to defend itself against a negative score. It's possible that
in the system in which it will live full time, that situation is never
going to happen, in which case, someone /else/ (like the module that
invokes this class) should check for such invalid data.

> > Finally, I should mention that this is not the kind of design problem I
> > have in mind when I made my admittedly baseless claim. Since it was
> > baseless, I should revise my claim. Here it is:
> >
> > When I write JUnit tests, I am forced to deal with dependency
> > problems in my code. I don't yet have any evidence that Agitator
> > would help me with that. I am concerned that since Agitator helps
> > me /not/ write JUnit tests, it might also help me /not/ feel the
> > pain of those kinds of dependency problems.
>
> I think it is a reasonable concern but not something to fear in
> practice. I don't think I've ever worked with a customer where I
> haven't pointed to the screen and said something about dependency
> injection.

In the hands of a thoughtful practitioner, I believe Agitator to be a
great thing. I am concerned that less-thoughtful practitioners will use
Agitator as an excuse not to write tests. I've heard it too many times
already. I should make it clear: that's not Agitator's fault. It's just
a statement about the product and what it does. Any product, of course,
can be abused.

> fwiw about the only JUnit tests that I haven't written becuase of
> Agitator are the ones I would have written to fix the bugs that would
> have otherwise have been reported. :)

This is exactly how I expect to use Agitator: to help me find the tests
I missed. When the day comes that I'm on a full-time Java project (if
that day ever comes again), I will insist on Agitator.
